title: Welcome to the Wired (PINNED)
content: Welcome to viztini's tech blog, here I explore the boundaries between the physical world and the wired (the cloud, the internet, the network, whatever you want to call it), the depths of technology, consciousness, and the ever-evolving digital landscape. Are you ready to disconnect from reality?

title: Welcome to the New Site
content:
I've completely overhauled the website to bring it back to the golden age of computing.

Enjoy the crisp gray backgrounds, the comforting teal desktop, and the satisfying click of un-smoothed fonts.

This new design is cleaner, faster, and more "Windows 95" than ever before.

Also open the developer console and type "bsod()" to see a system integrity violation.

title: Happy New Year!
content: I hope you all had a wonderful holiday break. Apologies for the lack of posts in December, I was away on holiday. I’m excited to be back and can’t wait to see what this year brings for technology!

title: Osaka '09
content:
Recently I have been working on my retro Linux Distro, Osaka '09.
Osaka ’09 is a handcrafted Linux distro inspired by the late‑2000s aesthetic of glossy UI chrome, soft gradients, and playful skeuomorphism. It blends the charm of Windows‑era design with a distinctly Japanese‑influenced retro‑modern vibe — a look that feels like it could’ve shipped on a 2009 ultrabook straight out of Umeda.

title: UNC2891 Hackers Use Linux Malware in Major Banking Security Heists
content:
UNC2891 slipped Raspberry Pi implants into ATM network paths, used simple Linux privilege-escalation tools, and hid their activity with bind mounts to quietly control transaction switches for years.

That foothold let them clone cards, run mule cashouts across multiple countries, and exploit long-standing structural weaknesses in banking networks that looked secure only on paper.

title: Offline LLMs Are Actually Useful Now
content:
Quantization, lightweight runtimes, and model distillation let multi-billion-parameter models run locally on laptops.

For privacy-first workflows and reproducible experiments, an offline model can be dramatically more practical than it was two years ago, that is if you accept some tradeoffs in latency and accuracy.

title: CLI over GUI
content:
Terminals outperform GUIs for anyone who knows their tools. Commands chain, automate, and scale in ways clicking never will.

A GUI shows options; a CLI lets you shape the system.
